hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.name: REGISTRY_REPO_NAME
hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.description: This is used to identify the name of the docker registry repository that this image is going to be pushed to

hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.name: ECR_REGISTRY_URL
hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.description: The url of the elastic container registry (ECR) where the newly created image is to be pushed to from this server and pulled from by the target docker host

hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.name: TOMCAT_VERSION
hudson.model.StringParameterDefinition.description: The value the image being built is to tagged with for identification within the local and registry repositories.

hudson.tasks.Shell.command:
# 2) Define variables. # NOTE: JENKINS_URL is the full URL of Jenkins, like http://server:port/jenkins/ # Only available if Jenkins URL is set in system configuration ECR_REPO_URL="${ECR_REGISTRY_URL}/${REGISTRY_REPO_NAME}" DOCKER_TAG="${ECR_REPO_URL}:tomcat${TOMCAT_VERSION}"
# 4) Login to the registry # NOTE: info on how to store credentials can be found at: # http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/topic/config-vars.html # requires ~/.aws/config # evalstr="$(aws ecr get-login --profile ecr.access)"
# NOTE: The ecr get-login command of the aws cli returns a docker command that includes a removed switch. # The -e (email) switch will be rejected by the newer version of docker that we have installed on our aws # ec2 instances to accomodate cloud watch logging from our containers. Therefore I am removing the offending # "-e none" portion of the command with the stream editor. # evalstr="$(echo $evalstr | sed 's/ -e none//')" # eval $evalstr
$(aws ecr get-login --no-include-email --region us-east-1)
# 5) Push the newly created image to the registry docker push ${DOCKER_TAG}
